latest news.eng_title: Boar's Head Plant Posed 'Imminent Threat' 2 Years Before Listeria Outbreak, USDA Documents Show
latest news.summary: USDA inspectors had warned that a Boar's Head plant in Virginia posed an 'imminent threat' two years before a listeria outbreak and recall of 7 million pounds of meat products. The inspection documents showed the plant had green mold, condensation, rusted equipment, beetles, and other unsanitary conditions. Between Aug. 1, 2023, and Aug. 2, 2024, inspectors found 'heavy discolored meat buildup' and 'meat overspray on walls.' A USDA spokesperson said the investigation into the listeria outbreak is ongoing and will include a 'top-to-bottom review' to determine contributing factors. Boar's Head has stopped production at the plant and is working with the USDA and industry experts to determine how the liverwurst was adulterated. 'We are conducting an extensive investigation, working closely with the USDA and government regulatory agencies, as well as with the industry's leading food safety experts, to determine how our liverwurst produced at our Jarratt, Virginia, facility was adulterated and to prevent it from happening again,' the company said.
latest news.title: Boar's Head Plant Posed 'Imminent Threat' 2 Years Before Listeria Outbreak, USDA Documents Show

latest news.eng_title: Check if your grocery store carried recalled Boar's Head deli meat
latest news.summary: The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has issued a recall for Boar's Head deli meat and Strassburger brand liverwurst due to contamination with listeria, a bacteria that can cause severe illness. The recalled products were sold at various retailers, including Target, Kroger, Safeway, and Jewel, and have a 44-day shelf-life. Consumers are advised to check their refrigerators for recalled meat and look for 'EST. 12612' or 'P-12612' inside the USDA mark of inspection on the product labels. Anyone who has recalled meat at home should throw it away or return it to the store, and those who purchased one of the 71 recalled deli products can contact the place of purchase for a refund. So far, the outbreak has been linked to 57 hospitalizations and nine deaths across 18 states. Health officials recommend heating deli meat to 165 degrees Fahrenheit before eating to kill any present bacteria, especially for high-risk individuals such as the elderly and pregnant people.
latest news.title: Check if your grocery store carried recalled Boar's Head deli meat

latest news.eng_title: ‘Major deficiencies' found at Boar's Head plant almost two years before deli meat recall, documents show
latest news.summary: Almost two years before a deadly listeria outbreak linked to recalled deli meat, inspectors at a Virginia Boar's Head plant found 'major deficiencies' in the physical conditions, including rusty equipment, mold, and a 'rancid smell in the cooler.' The reports, from the US Department of Agriculture's Food Safety Inspection Service, detailed poor conditions that 'could pose an imminent threat.' Despite being notified, the plant failed to address these issues, which ultimately led to the recall. The company has paused operations at the Virginia plant and is working with food safety experts to investigate the events leading to the recall. The USDA has stated that the establishment implemented corrective actions in keeping with FSIS regulations, but the actual number of illnesses is probably higher than what's been reported. The CDC continues to advise consumers to check their kitchens for recalled products.
latest news.title: ‘Major deficiencies' found at Boar's Head plant almost two years before deli meat recall, documents show

latest news.eng_title: Boar's Head plant posed ‘imminent threat' two years before deadly listeria outbreak

Organization: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

latest news.summary: The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) released reports showing that the Boar's Head plant in Virginia posed an 'imminent threat' two years before the recent deadly listeria outbreak. Inspectors noted issues such as rusted equipment, product buildup, and green mold on the wall. Despite these findings, the plant continued to operate and process its products. A spokesperson for Boar's Head stated that the inspectors' finding of an imminent threat in 2022 was not followed with any enforcement action. The company has since recalled 7 million pounds of products and temporarily stopped production. At least nine people died and over 60 were sickened by the outbreak, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) is investigating the listeria outbreak and conditions at Boar's Head establishments nationwide, stating, 'In addition to taking a holistic look at Boar's Head establishments across the country, our investigation will include a top-to-bottom review to determine contributing factors that led to the outbreak at this particular facility, what needs to be improved, and if there are lessons learned that could be more broadly applied to ready-to-eat meat and poultry facilities.'
latest news.title: Boar's Head plant posed ‘imminent threat' two years before deadly listeria outbreak

latest news.eng_title: USDA reports say Boar's Head's outbreak of listeria was 'imminent' at Virginia facility
latest news.summary: According to new records, the spread of listeria in the U.S. out of Boar's Head's facility in Virginia, which has killed several and hospitalized dozens, first showed an 'imminent' threat two years before the outbreak. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) detailed scores of disturbing health violations during inspections dating as far back as 2022 to August of this year, including mold and condensation issues, live beetles or insects, dirt and trash with product buildup on rusted and dirty equipment, and blood in puddles on the floor. Despite reports detailing the repeated violations, the 44-year-old Jarratt plant continued to operate. A company spokesperson pointed out that the inspector's findings were not followed by any enforceable USDA actions. Sarah Sorscher, a food safety regulatory expert, stated, 'They shouldn't have allowed this company to keep producing ready-to-eat products, lunch meat that's going to go on people's tables, when they're seeing this level of violation.' The CDC first reported on July 20 that a listeria outbreak tied to sliced deli meats had killed two and hospitalized at least 28 other people in 12 states. At least nine deaths and more than 60 hospitalizations have so far been reported in at least 17 states with known listeria cases tied directly to the Boar's Head outbreak. All operations at the plant have been suspended, and company officials have been working to disinfect the facility and retrain its current employees. More than 7 million pounds of Boar's Head meat products had been recalled in a public notice that still remains in effect.
latest news.title: USDA reports say Boar's Head's outbreak of listeria was 'imminent' at Virginia facility

latest news.eng_title: USDA reports say Boar's Head outbreak of listeria was 'imminent' at Virginia facility
latest news.summary: A listeria outbreak tied to sliced deli meats from Boar's Head's facility in Virginia has killed at least nine people and hospitalized over 60 others. According to the USDA, the facility had shown 'imminent' threat of listeria two years before the outbreak, with repeated health violations including mold, condensation, and live insects. Despite these findings, the facility continued to operate, and it wasn't until consumers had died that it was shut down. 'Consumers had to die before this plant got shut down, really is the bottom line,' said Sarah Sorscher, a food safety regulatory expert. The CDC has confirmed that the outbreak is the largest listeriosis outbreak since 2011, and all operations at the plant have been suspended. More than 7 million pounds of Boar's Head meat products have been recalled, and consumers are advised to check for any remaining products and heat them to an internal temperature of 165 degrees to prevent infection. 'They shouldn't have allowed this company to keep producing ready-to-eat products, lunch meat that's going to go on people's tables, when they're seeing this level of violation,' said Sorscher. 'It is a serious infection that primarily affects pregnant women, people 65 or older, or those with a weakened immune system.'
latest news.title: USDA reports say Boar's Head outbreak of listeria was 'imminent' at Virginia facility

latest news.eng_title: USDA flagged safety and health violations in Boar's Head plant years before listeria outbreak - Washington Examiner
latest news.summary: Federal food safety assessments in 2022 revealed serious safety and health violations at the Boar's Head plant, including live beetles, mold, and rust. Despite these reports, the USDA did not take enforcement action. Inspectors reported 60 days of 'noncompliances' between August 2023 and July 2024, including blood puddles, dirty machinery, and heavy meat buildup. The plant did not face consequences, and a listeria outbreak occurred, resulting in 9 deaths and dozens of hospitalizations. A food safety expert said, 'Consumers had to die before this plant got shut down, really is the bottom line.' Boar's Head recalled 3,500 tons of meat in July, but some of the affected meat may still be in consumers' possession, with an expiration date in October.
latest news.title: USDA flagged safety and health violations in Boar's Head plant years before listeria outbreak - Washington Examiner

latest news.eng_title: Boar's Head plant posed ‘imminent threat' 2 years before deadly listeria outbreak
latest news.summary: The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) released reports showing that the Boar's Head plant in Virginia was warned of an 'imminent threat' two years before a recent deadly listeria outbreak. The reports, released after the outbreak, showed the plant had issues such as rusted equipment, product buildup, and live beetles. Despite being informed of these problems, the plant continued to operate and process its products. A spokesperson for Boar's Head said that no enforcement action was taken after the USDA reviewed the results of testing, records, and observations. The plant has been temporarily stopped, and 7 million pounds of products were recalled after the outbreak, which killed at least nine people and sickened over 60. The USDA is investigating the outbreak and conditions at Boar's Head establishments nationwide. According to an FSIS spokesperson, 'In addition to taking a holistic look at Boar's Head establishments across the country, our investigation will include a top-to-bottom review to determine contributing factors that led to the outbreak at this particular facility, what needs to be improved, and if there are lessons learned that could be more broadly applied to ready-to-eat meat and poultry facilities.'
latest news.title: Boar's Head plant posed ‘imminent threat' 2 years before deadly listeria outbreak

news knowledge.eng_title: Recalled Meat Sold In Nebraska Spurs Ongoing Hospitalizations, Deaths
news knowledge.summary: Boar's Head Provisions Co. has expanded their recall of deli meat products sold in Nebraska due to possible Listeria monocytogenes contamination. The recall includes 7 million additional pounds of ready-to-eat meat and poultry products nationwide, with 71 total Boar's Head deli items affected. The recalled products were produced between May 10, 2024, and July 29, 2024, and have sell by dates ranging from July 29, 2024, to October 17, 2024. According to the USDA, 34 people in 13 states have been identified as sick, with 33 hospitalizations and two deaths. The FSIS warns that Listeria infection can cause serious illness in pregnant women, those over 65, and individuals with compromised immune systems, and advises those who experience symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and diarrhea to seek immediate medical attention within two months of eating contaminated food.
news knowledge.title: Recalled Meat Sold In Nebraska Spurs Ongoing Hospitalizations, Deaths

news knowledge.eng_title: Recalled Meat Sold In Illinois Spurs Ongoing Hospitalizations, Deaths
news knowledge.summary: Boar's Head Provisions Co. has expanded their recall of deli meat products sold in Illinois due to possible Listeria monocytogenes contamination. The recall includes 7 million additional pounds of ready-to-eat meat and poultry products nationwide, with 71 total Boar's Head deli items affected. The recalled products were produced between May 10, 2024, and July 29, 2024, and feature sell by dates ranging from July 29, 2024, to October 17, 2024. According to the USDA, 34 people have been identified as sick in 13 states, with 33 hospitalizations and two deaths. The FSIS warns that Listeria can cause serious infections in pregnant individuals, those over 65, and those with compromised immune systems, and advises individuals to seek immediate medical attention if they experience symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and gastrointestinal issues within two months of eating contaminated food.
news knowledge.title: Recalled Meat Sold In Illinois Spurs Ongoing Hospitalizations, Deaths

news knowledge.eng_title: Recalled Meat Sold In Minnesota Spurs Ongoing Hospitalizations, Deaths
news knowledge.summary: Boar's Head Provisions Co. has expanded their recall of deli meat products sold in Minnesota due to possible Listeria monocytogenes contamination. The recall includes 7 million pounds of ready-to-eat meat and poultry products, produced between May 10, 2024, and July 29, 2024, with sell-by dates ranging from July 29, 2024, to October 17, 2024. According to the USDA, 34 people have been identified as sick in 13 states, with 33 hospitalizations and two deaths. The FSIS warns that Listeria can cause serious infections in pregnant individuals, those over 65, and those with compromised immune systems, and advises individuals to seek medical attention if they experience symptoms such as fever, muscle aches, and gastrointestinal issues within two months of eating contaminated food.
news knowledge.title: Recalled Meat Sold In Minnesota Spurs Ongoing Hospitalizations, Deaths

news knowledge.eng_title: Boar's Head expands deli meat recall amid fatal listeria outbreak
news knowledge.summary: Boar's Head has expanded its recall of deli meats due to a listeria outbreak that has sickened 34 people across 13 states. The recall now includes 7 million pounds of ready-to-eat meat and poultry products produced between May 10 and July 29, 2024. The products were distributed to retail deli locations nationwide and have 'sell by' dates ranging from July 29 to October 17, 2024. According to the USDA, the problem was discovered when a sample collected by the Maryland Department of Health tested positive for L. monocytogenes. Boar's Head is cooperating with government authorities and conducting its own investigation into the incident. The CDC states that listeria can cause severe illness in pregnant people, those aged 65 or older, or anyone with a weakened immune system, and can be fatal in some cases.
news knowledge.title: Boar's Head expands deli meat recall amid fatal listeria outbreak

news knowledge.eng_title: Boar's Head Expands Recall Of Deli Meat Products Over Listeria Concern
news knowledge.summary: Boar's Head Provisions Co., Inc. is recalling an additional 7 million pounds of ready-to-eat meat and poultry products due to a listeria outbreak. The recall includes 71 products made between May 10 and July 29, with 'sell by' dates from July 29 to October 17. The products were distributed to retail stores across the nation and exported to several countries. As of July 30, 2024, 34 people have been identified as sick in 13 states, with 33 hospitalizations and two deaths. The USDA has urged customers to throw away or return the impacted product, and retailers are requested not to sell the recalled products.
news knowledge.title: Boar's Head Expands Recall Of Deli Meat Products Over Listeria Concern

news knowledge.eng_title: Massive deli meat recall tied to listeria outbreak: What to know
news knowledge.summary: Boar's Head is recalling 7 million pounds of deli meat products due to a listeria outbreak that has caused two deaths and over 30 illnesses. The recall includes 71 products produced between May 10 and July 29 at its Jarratt, Va., facility. The company has decided to pause ready-to-eat operations at this facility until further notice. The products have 'sell by' dates ranging from July 29 through Oct. 17, 2024. The USDA is working with the CDC and state public health organizations to investigate the multistate outbreak. Consumers and retailers are advised not to consume or sell the impacted products, and to thoroughly clean their refrigerators and deli areas to prevent cross-contamination. Boar's Head said, 'No words can fully express our sympathies and the sincere and deep hurt we feel for the families that have suffered losses and others who endured illness.'
news knowledge.title: Massive deli meat recall tied to listeria outbreak: What to know

news knowledge.eng_title: Boar's Head recalls 7 million more pounds of deli meat over listeria outbreak
news knowledge.summary: Boar's Head has expanded its recall of deli meats to 7 million pounds due to a listeria outbreak that has killed two people and made 34 others sick in 13 states. The recall includes 71 products under the Boar Head's and Old Country brands, including ham, bacon, sausage, and bologna, with a sell by date ranging from July 29, 2024 to October 17, 2024. The USDA is urging customers to throw away or return the products and clean their refrigerators to prevent cross-contamination. According to the CDC, listeria infections can cause serious symptoms, including high fever, headaches, and diarrhea, and can be fatal for young children, elderly people, and those with weakened immune systems. Boar's Head expressed its regret and sympathies for the families affected, saying, 'No words can fully express our sympathies and the sincere and deep hurt we feel for the families that have suffered losses and others who endured illness.'
news knowledge.title: Boar's Head recalls 7 million more pounds of deli meat over listeria outbreak

news knowledge.eng_title: Arizona impacted by Boar's Head recall of 7 million pounds of deli meat. What to know
news knowledge.summary: Boar's Head Brand has announced a recall of 7 million pounds of deli meat due to possible Listeria contamination. The recall affects Arizona and includes products such as bologna, ham, salami, and bacon, among others. The recalled items were sold under Boar's Head and Old Country Brand and had a 'sell by' date ranging from July 29, 2024, through October 17, 2024. According to the USDA, 34 people in 13 states were infected with listeriosis between May 29 and July 12, resulting in 33 hospitalizations and two deaths. The USDA urges individuals who bought the recalled items to throw them away or return to the place of purchase and to clean and sanitize refrigerators and deli equipment that came in contact with the recalled products. As stated by the USDA, 'serious cases can significantly affect those who are pregnant, 65 or older, or have a weakened immune system.'
news knowledge.title: Arizona impacted by Boar's Head recall of 7 million pounds of deli meat. What to know

news knowledge.eng_title: Stop & Shop temporarily closes delis again after Boar's Head recall expanded
news knowledge.summary: Stop & Shop temporarily closed their delis in Connecticut on Tuesday for deep cleaning and sanitization after Boar's Head expanded its recall of deli products due to listeria concerns. The company removed all impacted products from sale and discarded other open deli meats and cheeses that could have come into contact with the recalled items. This is in addition to the actions taken last week to discard open deli products and clean and sanitize the delis. According to the CDC, 34 people have gotten sick from eating the meat, 33 have been hospitalized, and two have died. The USDA recommends delis clean and sanitize all food and non-food surfaces and throw away any open meats and cheeses. Listeriosis can cause serious health concerns in people who are pregnant, over age 65, or have weakened immune systems.
news knowledge.title: Stop & Shop temporarily closes delis again after Boar's Head recall expanded

news knowledge.eng_title: Stop & Shop closes all store delis due to recall
news knowledge.summary: Stop & Shop has closed all of its store delis due to a recent recall of certain Boar's Head meat products. The USDA issued a recall for various ready-to-eat meats produced by Boar's Head between June 11 and July 17 due to possible listeria contamination. Stop & Shop is removing all impacted products from its in-store delis and discarding other meats and cheeses that may have been sliced or prepared in the same area. The company will also conduct a deep cleaning of its delis. 'As always, ensuring the safety of the products we sell is our highest priority,' Stop & Shop said in a statement.
news knowledge.title: Stop & Shop closes all store delis due to recall
